node.title: Blues thump Chiefs to win six straight as Crusaders pip Hurricanes
node.description: The Blues beat the Chiefs 25-0 in Hamilton on Saturday night as they kept the hosts scoreless for the first time in Super Rugby history.

node.title: Maryland lawmakers override governor's veto of abortion access
node.description: The measure comes at a time when the conservative majority on the U.S. Supreme Court is weighing whether to overturn Roe v. Wade.

node.title: Fewer than 12,000 foreign students remain in New Zealand
node.description: Immigration New Zealand figures show fewer than 12,000 foreign students remain in the country.

node.title: Man United and Arsenal slip up, Chelsea score six and Spurs win
node.description: Manchester United and Arsenal's Premier League top-four hopes were hit by defeats as Chelsea bounced back from their Champions League loss at Southampton.

node.title: Woody debris on Gisborne beaches again after recent flooding
node.description: The Gisborne mayor says prosecutions are possible if debris found on beaches following the recent flooding can be traced to a breach of a resource consent.

node.title: Covid-19 cases expected to climb again during winter
node.description: People's behaviour, waning immunity and any new variants will influence Covid-19 case numbers over winter, a modeller says.

node.title: 'Don't be a jerk': Badly behaved passengers hit with record fines
node.description: Two airline passengers accused of "unruly behaviour" have been hit with the largest fines ever proposed by the US Federal Aviation Administration.

node.title: Travel chaos for third day in a row at Sydney Airport
node.description: Sydney Airport has apologised as passengers express frustration over another day of delays.

node.title: Agriculture sector blamed for softer wording in climate change document
node.description: Greenpeace says New Zealand officials at the United Nations recently "sabotaged" efforts to mitigate climate change.

node.title: Jack White marries musician Olivia Jean at Detroit show
node.description: White asked her to marry him during a rendition of the song "Hotel Yorba" and right before the lyric "let's get married."

node.title: Pakistan's prime minister ousted after no confidence vote
node.description: The head of one of the largest opposition parties, the Pakistani Muslim League, will take over as prime minister.

node.title: Leclerc puts Ferrari on pole at Australian Grand Prix
node.description: Charles Leclerc took pole position for Ferrari in crash-laden qualifying for the Australian Grand Prix ahead of Red Bull's Max Verstappen.

node.title: U.K. prime minister meets with Ukraine's leader in Kyiv
node.description: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskyyâ€‹ said he was grateful for the prime minister's visit, calling it an important meeting during "very difficult and turbulent times for our country."

node.title: 'It just seems wrong': Council critic wants action on Blue Baths building
node.description: The former leaseholder says it's "not good enough" the council does not have a plan for the closed category one heritage-listed building in Rotorua.

node.title: Covid-19 update: 8531 new cases, 11 deaths, 635 in hospital
node.description: The number of new community cases of Covid-19 in New Zealand continues to fall, with 8531 new cases reported today, along with 11 further deaths.

node.title: Three people killed in shooting at Georgia gun range
node.description: The owner of the Lock Stock & Barrel Shooting Range in rural Coweta County was killed, along with his wife and grandson.

node.title: Scheffler leads Masters, Tiger stays in the hunt
node.description: A battling Tiger Woods clawed his way out of early trouble to stay in the Masters hunt carding a second round two-over 74 where the wind gave him more problems than his leg.

node.title: Why the Masters' green jacket is the holy grail of golf
node.description: The first Masters champion awarded with a green jacket was Sam Snead in 1949.

node.title: More Americans prefer daylight saving time to standard time
node.description: There's little support for switching clocks back and forth.

node.title: In a first, commercial crew docks with space station
node.description: The first non-government, privately-funded crew docked at space station Saturday for NASA-sanctioned research.

node.title: Dwayne Haskins, quarterback for Pittsburgh Steelers, dies at age 24
node.description: Steelers head coach Mike Tomlin confirmed Dwayne Haskins' death in a statement Saturday, calling him a "great teammate" and "tremendous friend to so many."

node.title: 17-year-old Ukrainian girl remains in U.S. border custody
node.description: Thousands of Ukrainians have been traveling to Mexico to seek asylum along the U.S. southern border since Russia invaded Ukraine.

node.title: After deadly train station strike, Ukraine's leader wants tough response
node.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said a missile strike on the Kramatorsk train station in eastern Ukraine amounted to another war crime for an international tribunal to consider.

node.title: Saudi Arabia expands Hajj to 1m pilgrims
node.description: Participants from outside the kingdom will be allowed after two years of tight Covid-19 restrictions.

node.title: Covid-19 hits Waikato Bay of Plenty Magic netballers
node.description: Two anticipated round five ANZ Championship netball games featuring the Waikato Bay of Plenty Magic have been postponed.

node.title: Political blacklist a sign Russia playing the victim - expert
node.description: A global politics professor says Russia is trying to paint itself as the victim of unjustified sanctions, as it blacklists New Zealand politicians.

node.title: Vehicle rebates miscalculated due to flawed emissions data
node.description: The Transport Agency says it is dealing with almost 100 vehicles with flawed emissions data under the Clean Car Discount Scheme.

node.title: Protest camp springs up in Christchurch's Latimer Square
node.description: A protest camp has sprung up in Christchurch's Latimer Square, where signs and tents have been hammered into the grass.

node.title: Will Smith banned from attending Oscars for 10 years after slap
node.description: Hollywood's film academy has banned Will Smith from attending the Oscars for 10 years after the actor slapped presenter Chris Rock on stage at this year's Academy Awards ceremony.

node.title: Local Government Commission axes Gisborne's rural wards
node.description: Gisborne District Council will be without rural ward councillors at its next election following a Local Government Commission hearing, missing out on its preferred option.
